Situation1: They prepare a structured session to teach important skills before a project deadline.
Situation2: They spot a child struggling in the deep end where swimming is restricted.
Story: I stood at the edge of the pool, clipboard in hand, watching my group of eager interns gather for our session. I’d spent hours preparing this lesson, determined to give them the tools they needed before their big project deadline. They looked to me for guidance, expecting insight and structure, and I felt the weight of their anticipation. Just as I began to explain the first concept, a sudden splash caught my attention. Out of the corner of my eye, I saw a small child flailing in the deep end—an area strictly off-limits for non-swimmers. My heart pounded. As a lifeguard, I was responsible for every life in the pool, expected to enforce safety and act instantly in emergencies. But as a mentor, I was supposed to be present, focused, and supportive, especially now, with so much riding on this session. I felt torn, the demands of both roles pulling me in opposite directions, my mind racing as I stood frozen between the group of interns and the struggling child.
